comment_data.body: Surely you still need to check if the match succeeded?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -26,34 +26,21 @@ local function format_message_with_content_length(message)
   })
 end
 
----@class (private) vim.lsp.rpc.Headers: {string: any}
----@field content_length integer
-
---- Parses an LSP Message's header
+--- Extract content-length from the msg header
 ---
----@param header string The header to parse.
----@return vim.lsp.rpc.Headers#parsed headers
-local function parse_headers(header)
-  assert(type(header) == 'string', 'header must be a string')
-  --- @type vim.lsp.rpc.Headers
-  local headers = {}
-  for line in vim.gsplit(header, '\r\n', { plain = true }) do
+---@param header string The header to parse
+---@return integer?
+local function get_content_length(header)
+  for line in header:gmatch('(.-)\r\n') do
     if line == '' then
       break
     end
-    --- @type string?, string?
-    local key, value = line:match('^%s*(%S+)%s*:%s*(.+)%s*$')
-    if key then

comment_data.body:
Could we shim `string.buffer` for PUC Lua? Even if it doesn't help performance there, it would simplify the code here and encourage more use of `string.buffer`.

~~if chatgpt is correct, the shim module doesn't look too onerous:~~

<details>
<summary>wrong code from chatgpt</summary>

```lua
-- buffer.lua
-- A Lua 5.1 module that emulates LuaJIT's string.buffer

local Buffer = {}
Buffer.__index = Buffer

-- Creates a new buffer
function Buffer.new()
    return setmetatable({ data = {} }, Buffer)
end

-- Appends data to the buffer
function Buffer:put(value)
    table.insert(self.data, value)
end

-- Appends formatted data to the buffer
function Buffer:putf(format, ...)
    table.insert(self.data, string.format(format, ...))
end

-- Retrieves the current buffer contents as a single string
function Buffer:get()
    return table.concat(self.data)
end

-- Resets the buffer
function Buffer:reset()
    self.data = {}
end

return Buffer
```
</details>
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -49,70 +49,102 @@ local header_start_pattern = ('content'):gsub('%w', function(c)
   return '[' .. c .. c:upper() .. ']'
 end)
 
+
+local has_strbuffer, strbuffer = pcall(require, "string.buffer")

comment_data.body:
Looks like with puc lua 5.1 we can't support `#buf` because `__len` doesn't work on tables.
Might be possible to implement it in c and expose as userdata where `__len` afaik should work.

comment_data.body: Even if the shim just applies to this module it would mean we don't need 2 versions of the same function.

comment_data.body:
Had a quick look at this but a lua shim would imho make it even more complicated. Emulating skip and the consume behavior of `:get`  would either be slower than before or more complex than the existing solution. 

I'd either keep the PR as is or just close this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -49,70 +49,102 @@ local header_start_pattern = ('content'):gsub('%w', function(c)
   return '[' .. c .. c:upper() .. ']'
 end)
 
+
+local has_strbuffer, strbuffer = pcall(require, "string.buffer")

comment_data.body:
Presumably there would be no shim for the LuaJIT version? In which case I don't think it's a problem if the PUC-Lua version is a bit slower.

Could also mean we'd be able to use this in more places.

comment_data.body: Having two quite different implementations for a complicated function that sits really low in the stack is a bit of a risk, whilst also introducing some debt, and late in the dev cycle. One has comments and the other doesn't. Having a single function should mitigate that a little. Though I guess this has been somewhat dog fed.

comment_data.body:
Honestly, this was something I had planned to do, but was beat to it, so I've minimised introducing changes to this file to avoid conflicting this PR.

The third choice I'm indirectly suggesting is that this waits until post 0.11. Then a follow-up is a more reasonable proposition and gives it longer to bake.

comment_regular_data.body: The "Performance" section of `:help news` is lonely, would be worth adding a minor note like `LSP: use string.buffer for RPC work`

> The "Performance" section of `:help news` is lonely

Because ci doesn't warn about news entry for "perf" commit type. Should we add that?
@mfussenegger Is this still on the docket and ready for 0.11?

> @mfussenegger Is this still on the docket and ready for 0.11?

Yes it would be ready. I was waiting on a response to https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/31520#discussion_r1900087839 

(Note also that I merged the same change back in December in nvim-dap: https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-dap/pull/1394 - so far with no negative feedback)
Let's slap a ~~brag~~ news entry on it and merge this then.
Feel free to pick this up
